s.text: A Scud missile exploded over the 24th Naval Battalion, exposing its soldiers to rocket propellant and, some claim, mustard gas --a weapon used to rapidly induce blindness and severe skin burns.
For example, the engineers of the battalion exposed to sarin showed no higher illness rates than others.
Other studies of Gulf War vets show no higher rates of hospitalization, birth defects, or death than among control groups that did not serve.
For example, the engineers of the battalion exposed to sarin showed no higher illness rates than others.
Other studies of Gulf War vets show no higher rates of hospitalization, birth defects, or death than among control groups that did not serve.
But exposure levels in the Gulf were not high enough to cause such reactions.
Gulf veterans and their supporters point to evidence that troops encountered many different chemical agents which, they believe, made thousands ill after coming home.
